title: 114_hr2200
content: The Act titled "CBRN Intelligence and Information Sharing Act of 2015" amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include provisions for Chemical, Biological, Radiological, and Nuclear intelligence and information sharing. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis of the Department of Homeland Security supports intelligence analysis of terrorist actors planning attacks involving chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear materials, global infectious diseases, and homeland security risk assessments. The Office of Intelligence and Analysis within the Department of Homeland Security enhances prevention, protection, response, and recovery efforts related to chemical, biological, radiological, or nuclear attacks. It shares tailored analytical support on these threats with State, local, and tribal authorities, as well as other national biosecurity stakeholders and Federal agencies. Coordination with relevant Department components and the Intelligence Community is also emphasized. The curr_chunk discusses collaboration with various entities in the Intelligence Community and other authorities to enhance information sharing mechanisms and provide recommendations. It also provides definitions for terms used in the section. The curr_chunk provides definitions for the terms 'Intelligence Community' and 'national biosecurity and biodefense stakeholders'. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of contents in the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report annually to Congress on intelligence and information sharing activities related to countering threats from chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear materials, as well as the Department's compliance with relevant intelligence strategies. The Secretary of Homeland Security must report annually to Congress on intelligence and information sharing activities related to countering threats from chemical, biological, radiological, and nuclear materials. The report shall include a description of methods to assess progress in implementing the Office of Intelligence and Analysis amendment and its termination after a 5-year period. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to disseminate information to State, local, tribal, and private entities to prevent terrorism. Passed by the House of Representatives on June 25, 2015.
